newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - SFE options, SYCOM trading set new records.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - SFE options, SYCOM trading set new records.

text.p: Options trading on the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) and trading on the overnight computerised SYCOM system both set records in 1995/96, SFE said.
Options trading rose 9.7 percent to a record 3.1 million contracts. This included 30 percent growth in 90-day bank bill options and 13 percent growth in 10 year treasury bond options.
Share Price Index futures trading rose 16 percent to a record 2.6 million contracts. Bank bill futures trading was steady, down by 0.8 percent in nominal contract value.
Overnight SYCOM trading rose by 18 percent, the SFE said.
Bond futures were down by 11 percent because of flat interest rate conditions, the exchange said.

SFE chief executive Les Hosking said 1995/96 mirrored trading activity in the cash and over-the-counter derivatives markets during an unprecedented period of stability in official government interest rates.

"While there was stability in official Australian interest rates, volatility in the U.S. bond and equity markets ensured further growth in trading activity on SFE's overnight trading system SYCOM," he said.
By being the only Australian market open through the night, SYCOM allowed Australian market participants to respond instantly to market changes, Hosking said.
So far in calendar 1996, overnight option trading was five times higher than 1995, reflecting the need for cover from overnight volatility, he said.
